[h1]Lava[/h1]
I shall begin this review by saying that the game is playable, despite the "Early Access" tag. However, I had some expectations that were crushed:
[list]
[*]Drillships are not used to destroy other drillship.
[*]You have to go by foot to destroy one.
[*]...Without any protections. Guns are implemented in the game but not body armor.
[*]Lava is not your enemy here, the robots are.
[*]Volcano eruptions are a mere annoyance. It's just a matter of reaching safety in time, regularly.
[*]Enemies are using [i]hitscan[/i] weapons.
[/list]
But nevertheless it was enjoyable.

The game revolves around upgrading your drillship (tier) to progress the game. The goal is to destroy all 3 laser... device [spoiler]plus another one, just heavily guarded by T4 drillships[/spoiler]. Sounds pretty simple, isn't it? All of the laser devices are gated behind each tier. In order to upgrade your drillship, you'll need to do research for the new module, deploy the new module in the drillship, and craft the upgrade using the new module.

The tutorial quests is just so go[noparse]dda[/noparse]mn robust, you can just rely your progress on them, all the way until the ending. The quest system will tell you not only what you'll have to do, but where to get all the materials for the crafting, what you have to do in order to craft, point at the nearest material source, and tells you if the material you're looking is already in the drillship storage. It's not perfect, but it's way better than what you see in other games. Wow.

The robots (known as COGs here) is the real killer. All of their weapons are [i]hitscan[/i], meaning that all it takes to plant the bullet in your body is to pull the trigger right when it points to your body. They don't even have to aim, they have aimbot (no joke, sometimes their aiming animation gets bugged and fails to show, but they fire anyway and you get hit). As a rule of thumb, green bots (almost) never misses (but deals low damage), red bots misses a lot (but deals high damage).

NOTE: In the news, they'll be announcing for [i]projectile[/i] weapons, which actually simulates a bullet going through that can be dodged, unlike hitscan.

Really, at the current stage, the game is more of an offensive play and less of a defensive play. On your own, the only tools you only have are weapons, pickaxe (you can use it as melee) and medkit to heal you (it takes 5 sec to use). No body armor or shields to reduce your damage. The only strategy is to kill the robots before they kill you.

NOTE: They're announcing that they'll be adding body armor in the next update (and even "power armor" in the future), so expect this information to be obsolete.

You can continue playing after completing the game, but no robots will spawn, volcano will stop erupting ("Volcano eruption in ∞") , and (presumably) no ores will spawn. It's actually boring after that, but who cares about the ending? Just forget that last quest and keep killing those clankers!

Despite all the weaknesses, there is one good thing about it: no rush on winning the game. Volcano eruption sets a timer on how long you can work on the surface but never set how fast you have to progress through the game. You can find a lone spot in the underground caverns where you won't be attacked by bots. Resources respawn, so you won't be afraid on running out of them. Take your time.

But hey, there's multiplayer if you need a helping hand from your friend... and an official Discord server if you're asking for a friend... if your game is set to multiplayer from the beginning (unless you manually edit your solo save into multiplayer).

Also, if you're playing this game, know that you can press G to remotely send your drillship to underground and back, while you hide from other places (you can hide in shelters, mines, or submarine).

[h1]Buy and forget until out of Early Access?[/h1]
Put this in your library for a few months. The updates are slow but consistent. The game has been actively developed for months. The developers does listen to the community and actually implemented them, but, y'know, time and resources are finite.

This game doesn’t really deserve a thumbs down, but it doesn’t deserve a thumbs up either.  It's kind of in the middle. Maybe one day steam will allow me to post a review with a neutral rating.  However, due to a bad design decision that is common in a lot of not-so-good games, I chose the thumbs down instead of thumbs up.

What I liked:
The aesthetic of the game is wonderful.  I really like the steampunk look and feel.  

I also like the idea of this mobile base that you take with you.  You can upgrade it to add better facilities and even make it into a very large ship.

The graphics, sound, and animation are good for what the game is.  Nothing earth shattering, but it certainly could be worse.

Load times are very quick.  I would normally not mention this, except for a few recent games I have played that are slow to load.

What I didn’t like:
There are two main activities you spend most of your time on.  Maybe 90% of your time.

The first one is on a 2d map, where you drive the icon of your ship around exploring an area and collecting resources like iron, copper, and coal.

The second activity is spending time in your drill ship while it's parked somewhere, watching crafting timers.  So you  have a research station that is doing research where you queue up and just watch a meter go.  Then a refinery to turn iron ore into iron ingots.  Then a crafting station to turn ingots into parts into whatever it is you want.  All this takes a lot of time and there isn’t much to do.  

You might think you want to park your ship and go exploring while all this crafting is going on, but that isn't viable because the crafting queues are so small.  By the time you got anywhere, your factories would be done and you would need to return to your ship.  Also you can only walk in caves or the overworld.  The overworld only has basic resources which you do not need after the beginning of the game.  The caves only have a VERY limited number of nodes to mine as well so there isn’t much to do there either.  So basically find a book to read or something while all this crafting is going on.

The basic game-play loop is to kill a drillship, get a foozle from it, then do the above loop until everything is upgraded to the next tier and then find another drillship to kill in order to get foozle level +1 and do the loop again.  That is almost the entire game-play.

What I REALLY didn’t like:
Combat really sucks in this game.  You get torn up even with your best armor and best weapons.  Your one dude against an infinitely respawning army.  You weapons would need to be MUCH more powerful to deal the waves dues they throw at you near the end game.  Its not challenging, but absurd.

For example, there is a quest to kill a tier 4 drill ship.  This is a huge ship that has like 8 spawners for cogs.  Not just any cogs, but top tier cogs.  It took me like 10 attempts to take one out.  My strategy was to make a bunch of save games at certain points where I was doing well so I could restart from that point again when everything went to hell. 

At one point I am in a corridor in the enemy drill ship with a gatling gun going full blast and there are so many cogs spawning that I can’t make any headway.  So I just have to duck out and find the spawners and take them out one by one, all the while the timer to the next eruption is counting down.  But I beat it.  The ONE tier 4 drill ship.

So I make it to the final mission, which is to take a giant laser thingy which is supposedly making the volcano.  Well this baby is guarded by not one, not two, but THREE tier 4 ships cranking out the cogs.  Now if my weapons and armor didn’t suck (I had the best the game offered as far as I can tell), then maybe I could have done it.  I tried for a while and gave up because it's just WTF insane.  This is on “Normal” difficulty BTW.  

Part of the problem is that Armor isn’t armor.  It doesn’t reduce damage. Its just extra HP.  Now if titian armor gave you like 90% damage reduction rather than 4 bars of health (which can evaporate in seconds) then you might be able to do a lot better.  Also changing armor or using a health pack takes a very long time as far as combat is concerned.

The major design flaw that this game is guilty of (and they are NOT alone in making this error) as far as the end-game is that they do not have any real creative idea of what to do for the finally of their game.  So what do they do?  Just throw waves of dudes as you and call it a day.  So many games fail in their design this way.  You read reviews that say something like, it was a good game for the most part, but at the end it all fell apart.  All other mechanics go out the window and they throw a bunch of bad guys at you.  

I have no idea where they can go with the design.  Maybe when it's done I'll check it out again.  Maybe they will have figured out what they want to do with the game by then.

Some small suggestions in case the devs read this:
 Make production smart.  Let me pick the end product and have the manufacturing system make all the things in between.
Make armor actual armor and not just some extra HP.
Improve combat and the weapons to handle waves of bad guys.  Maybe if the gatling gun had explosive ammo that not only did more damage, but was an AoE, that would help a lot.

Slightly bigger suggestion.  Let us build an army of our own cogs.  Maybe the end battle would not be so ridiculous as it is now.  Also these cogs should be able to collect corpses of other dead cogs to re-cycle into new cogs.

Not great, not terrible. Better than what most of the early access games give you in the genre, and has an ending already. Took around 10 hours to finish.

There are a few design choices that don't seem to make a whole lot of sense that I overlooked due to this being out as early access:
- Stamina isn't used for anything (except sprinting), and there's an absurd amount of it. There are no upgrades that give you more stamina. It does run out eventually, but overall it feels like it was added without much thought put into why it exists, and sprint could easily just be replaced with an infinite sprint without breaking game balance in any way.
- At times it felt like the game is punishing you for playing it, as there is nothing you can build to the drillship to adequately defend it from AI attack waves. There didn't seem to be any way to automate repairs, so you end up having to run around your ship repairing things if you don't want anything to break, given how little health all the modules (even later tier ones) have. In other words, it feels like the game is punishing you for even thinking about leaving the ship, unattended, but camping it with repairs is not what I'd imagine to be the intended experience here. We actually ended up skipping the last ship length expansion because it seemed unmanageable, running around three compartments already took long enough.
- Making it so you need lower tier resources to craft higher tier modules (at least when advancing tiers the first time) seems like a gimmick that forces you to spend a lot of time traveling around different tier zones, feels like I'm playing Albion online again (which had it by design). Making lower tier resources available via some means in higher tier areas, or shortcuts between zones (T3 to T1 directly without passing T2 for example) would make this better.

The ship defense in particular seems like an area that could be made a lot more engaging, as it was, we ended up using remote control to send it underground when we left the ship to move around as the constant AI sieges against it would slowly destroy it regardless of what defenses were set up. So we ended up avoiding the ship defense fights almost entirely near the end game as it just made no sense.

All in all, not great, not terrible, definitely a lot better than some other early access titles of the genre.

Not ready yet. Judging by the earlier reviews, might never be.
Volcanoids has a nice visual style and most of the right elements... in all the wrong places, packaged with annoying UI/UX. Many things could have been fixed in a very short time, it doesn't seem to be happening any time soon. May be fun right now for 10-20 hours you can squeeze of it, if you can overlook the resource management tedium, but don't expect anything more. I will be watching for updates, though.

Let's explore the problems in detail...
The game is open world only in the most technical sense. Zone progression is very clear and linear. Technical progression is clunky, but, again, linear. Exploration is limited, you only need to find several fixed points (mines and ammo resource spawn points) in your first playthrough, then... the map is fixed in its entirety. The quest system basically walks you through the entirety of the game, decomposing every task into step-by-step tutorial, then marking every subtask location on your map (a hard mode without quests exists, but is locked behind the first victory, and what's the point?).

The progression is a mess. There is an extreme tendency towards spiking, with you first having to do a quest after a quest without actual rewards, then accessing a bunch of stuff all at once. Combined with quest & zone progression, it means that you arrive in a new zone, get pwned for a while, having to do storm the enemy drillships with outdated weaponry and regularly falling back to your turrets, then get the updates that make you overpowered, retrofit your ship and move on. Basically, every zone is backloaded.

The resource system is a mess, too. Every zone - a third of the island - has its specific set of ores (geology has left the chat). You can't easily return to an earlier zone, and if you do, it's going to be very, very boring. You continue to need earlier resources, though, with the main offender being black powder, used for much of the late-game ammo in a massive quantities. Good thing that there are exploits that allow resource conversion (from crystal via SMG turret ammo, from copper via lights - chemistry has left the chat, too), but it shouldn't really work this way.

Then, you have a resource overload via secondaries and chains (the longest one being ore/scrap to metal to bullet casings to ammo to turret ammo, all from almost the start). It's very annoying to manage by hand. Good thing that there is automation via resource hubs (on infinite/threshold mode), bad thing that it is a massive resource hog, my setup spent almost a half of its energy on standby (most of the time they simply wait till I bring in some loot to disassemble/take some consumables to replace).

The inventory is a mess, too: you're limited by a slot count, every weapon takes up a slot, every consumable - a slot (grenades in the midgame tend to take many more, the first L2 drillship raids took us tens of grenades), every kind of a loot - at least, a slot: every resource has its own limits on how much one slot can contain. No ammo standardization between guns, lots of consumables, lots of resources results in slot juggling a little two often. It extends to the ship storage, too: it is also limited by a slot count, the slots are just hidden via grouping, took me a while to notice that all my inventory was eaten by the unsmelted iron ore (10 per slot as ore, 40 as an ingot).

Inventory and resource management is horribly plagued by UI/UX issues. UI is heavily modal, meaning that you normally see one specialized screen. You need to reference several screens at once, mainly production (sometimes several tabs)/scrap (several tabs)/ship storage (long scrolling), rarer research. Why? One place to see how much stuff you need, another to order it, one back to take it out, similar for every use case. Production and scrap are on different devices, no quick access for you. Then, structuring within tabs is simply bad, with player ammo being grouped with turret ammo (you basically never need to have it on hand) and not getting grouped with other consumables, and consumables being grouped with weapons, because they are all 'tools'. Also, sorting within the 'devices' tab (intra-ship buildings, basically) is insane. Ship storage sorting is insane, too, and filtering by type is somewhat unwieldy. Functions like "reload all weapons" (to fill the magazines) are missing, "fill the slot to max", too, wasting my time regularly in a very annoying manner. And don't even get me started on how long it took to set up automation (and find out how I can avoid returning to the beginning for the black powder).

The inventory/storage is used for things it shouldn't: schematics and upgrades. Would it be too hard to have an upgrade button that can be pressed once, autoinstall stuff after it gets researched/produced (I seem to have seen it on the last upgrades!), then disappears forever? I actually created extra schematics - that can't even be scrapped - several times by mistake. Of course, it would mean that you can't create stuff for other ships, but you control just one, and it's the best one you can have, ever. As an aside, the fact that research, upgrades and modules is not well explained in game, is very, very unhelpful, too.

The building system is similarly unwieldy, with possibly the same culprit: everything goes through storage, so you first look how much stuff (and where) you need, then run to your production station to order it, take it out (good luck remembering if you had to switch contexts in between), then return to place it. No planning mode, obviously. Then there are issues with device sizes (not really standardized, and, say, hubs are too honking big), too coarse a grid (symmetry breaks and clipping are common and painful), not enough wall slots. Also, there is an imbalance between short and long sections: the short ones tend to be where action happens, and they are tight, the long ones are annoyingly empty: simply not enough stuff to place inside. Also, the decision to disable some products for normal productions stations and allow them only for hubs is freaking evil, cost me a bunch of time running around: couldn't fit all the needed stuff into my cabin. ]:( Also, the inventory limit strikes again. Same with modules, minus positioning, plus 'fun' times moving doors (disassemble one, get four slots in inventory) and storages when close to the cap. By the way, why can't we disassemble the window module from the start? It was the most annoying trophy in existence.

Some more UI stuff: where is my minimap? I can open the large map at will anyway, and it's freaking unwieldy. Why distance limit for teammate markers? Backpacks? Why extreme zoom-in on pilot map (again, I can open the large map at will, and have to do so all the time)? The default control scheme is insane (WTF scroll to change ammo?), fixable, though.

The combat system is actually decent: apparently, messing up FPS is hard. Absence of recoil is boring (WTF handheld gatling?), but it's not actually mandatory. The bullet ballistics was surprising, to say at least - bullets feel more like arrows - but it's something I can live with (tracer bullets would be nice, though). There seem to be only one major balance issue: freaking teslas are everywhere and they heavily spoil the fun, shooting down grenades/mines (how am I supposed to anti-tank?) and semi-stun you.

There are standard optimization issues: the game seems incapable of getting over 60 FPS even on high-end hardware. Interestingly, it fails to utilize all available resources, both CPU and GPU.

Why the rant?
Basically, I've got at least ten unfun hours where I could have ten fun hours or, at least, no hours, with little expenditures from the developer. I mean, three quarters of the list could be fixed in a month, some of it even by a game designer working alone. Seeing obvious problems continuing for a long time is disturbing, considering the overall work done.

EDIT: I have beaten the game completely at just over 7 hours. I am updating my review based on my experience after writing my previous review. 

When I first saw Volcanoids on the front page of Steam, I was very interested. From what I saw in the reviews at the time, there was a lot of praise, so I decided to buy a copy and play for myself. After beating the game, however, I would recommend buyers to be wary about purchasing a copy at this time.

Volcanoids is very much centered around the drill you acquire in the beginning of the game. The drill's menu's are hard to pick up at first, and easy to navigate within the first hour or two. Your drill itself is unable to collect resources, so you must collect them manually. Your drill will be the refinery for those resources, as well as the hub for production to upgrade your drill and craft new items. It is also your research hub for upgrades, as well as your storage. Basically, whatever you can't do yourself, your drill will be doing the rest of.

That is my biggest issue at the moment. The game in its current state is too focused on this drill. There is manual resource gathering, you will use your starter pickaxe to gather most of the resources you'll need, and you never have to upgrade it. Your starter shotgun, one of the only two weapons you receive currently and is not upgradeable save for the bullets it uses, is used to kill enemies along with grenades, which by themselves aren't useful except for destroying enemy systems.

These systems are barebones compared to the drill, which the missions system, research, and most of production is focused around. Most of your game time will be sat in the drill, waiting for resources or parts to be made, or waiting for research to be completed, or designing an indoor portion of your drill with the small amount of design options that are available currently. When you run out of resources, you will have to go outside and collect them with your pickaxe, or by raiding an enemies storage crate in their drill, something that currently isn't worth the risk and resources for such a paltry reward.
 
While your drill cannot harvest ores by itself, it can take you to any of the 35 points in the map to collect resources from. You cannot control the drill except to move to these points, or to go underground about every 15 minutes to avoid a punctual volcano explosion that will instantly kill you if you or your drill are not underground when it goes boom. 

There are about 3 sections of the map. The drill will be unable to move through Sections 2 and 3 without the proper upgrades, which takes time to research and deploy. To continue, you will have to destroy lava drills in each underground sector of the map, which is easy enough as long as you have enough grenades and med packs. That will be your only difficulty, because enemy units in this game are very easy to kill, while their drill spawn points are unkillable, making them a constant nuisance. Two shots with your shotgun should kill just about any enemy very easily. Enemy drills cannot be destroyed, only looted.

My other main gripes are that there is no in-game music other than in the main menu, which makes the experience feel even emptier than it is. Also, that the missions system only focuses on defeating lava drills and upgrading your own drill, there is no unique mission other than in the beginning to take your drill. 

All in all, I cannot recommend players purchase the game at this time, because of the lack of content in most aspects of the game. I think that, hopefully in a few months time, there will be enough content that I can change my review, but at this stage the game is much to grindy and barebones.

TL;DR: The game is barebones except for the drill, gameplay is grindy and boring, wait a few months to check back in.

[h1]Volcanoids[/h1]

Volcanoids has the player building, customizing, upgrading, and adding onto their own unique Drill base to their hearts content, growing it into a long and winding serpentine Drill fortress to explore and survive amongst the constantly erupting island. As it turns out there's something much more sinister, much more mechanical going on under the surface of the island's volcano than just a simple act of Mother Nature. 

From the rusty scraps of your starter drill its up to the player to gather the necessary elements from the harsh environments of the volcanic island to craft their way up through the necessary tools of survival, allowing exploration deeper and deeper into the mysterious core.

[h1]Crafting, Refining, and Other Tasks[/h1]
 
Stations are built for the usual crafting tasks and the number of options feels at first daunting and convoluted, but its more-or-less a fancy way to separate and organize your storage and building queue. The real challenge comes from balancing the required Energy needed to power each of the Stations, as the more you build the more power you sap up.

Storage stations are compartments that store your important materials and receive your finished crafted components up to a certain limit, Refinery stations turn raw mined materials into craftable metals, and the Production stations are where the player puts them all together for new items, weapons, tools, ship components and upgrades. Where you build each of these stations is up to you, as is how you decide to power and use them. The only thing that's for certain is you [b]will[/b] run out of space as you need more tasks performed, and expansions onto your growing Drill vehicle will eventually be needed.

[h1]Setting and Exploration[/h1]

The post-apocalyptic little volcanic tropical island villages actually have a lot to see for its quaint size, tons of resources to gather throughout threatening caves of magma, and a lot of robots to blast between it all. Luckily with the drill-like nature of the steam-engine players can quickly burrow into the ground and traverse to different parts of the map, making full exploration and excavation of the bountiful island much quicker and easier.

Not only does this drilling process look pretty cool, its hotspot-hopping island traversal mechanic is particularly useful for cutting down on traveling time between important landmarks and necessary gathering sweetspots. As you venture out further you'll come across more and more points for your drill to embark on, allowing you to quickly traverse the natural island and especially comes in handy when needing to escape the trajectory of a massive volcanic eruption.

The entire idea of surviving on a periodically exploding island of volcanic death, scrambling to steam-powered behemoths for cover and escaping the clutches of 50's scifi movie style robots makes this a standout title in an otherwise saturated demographic of crafting sandboxes.
 
A real "steampunk" survival title is something that was really missing from the genre, and Volcanoids serves it up more than well with all of the creative steam powered vehicles and dystopic bells and whistles you'd want. The most monotonous aspect of survival sandbox titles is the gathering, but with such a fleshed out and imaginative world and an interesting twist of steampunk robotic forces to come across I was always excited to get back out and explore again.

[h1]Shooting; Overly Simple but Still Engaging[/h1]

The shooting is rather simple but its effective, as the player can blast away the hordes of robotic mobs away with a simple click of their classic pelletgun. This helps clear the way while hunting those much needed resources that hordes of enemies tend to gather around. The deeper you excavate the closer you get to the mechanical source of the tremors rocking the island, and the more diabolical the enemies and their designs become within their home of magma and rock.

[h1]FInal Thought[/h1]

Volcanoids is full of some incredibly grand ideas and in execution they're all pretty cool, but in its early access stage they do feel a bit limited. The setting, the enemies, the periodic destruction and transformation of the landscape are some of the most engaging prospects in the survival genre, but some of the features such as combat feel like more of an afterthought to the setting. 

The combat is fun and supplements the exciting exploration well but it feels all-too simplistic,  and the current travelling features for the drill feel more like a glorified teleportation system than any real kind of vehicular interaction which may dissapoint some. Having some more control over our Drill or the weapons/turrets we install would add to that awesome interactivity and in turn the deeper connection players feel with their hard-earned constructions.

All in all, Volcanoids is an ambitious new vision for the sandbox survival genre with more than enough room to grow. The core mechanics are in place and though some of the action may be a bit lackluster at the moment, the game has an incredible backdrop and setting with tons of potential lore to explore for the developers to build around. Very excited to see where Volcanoids is headed.

I had to mull over my thoughts for this one... Volcanoids has some charm, that's for sure, and there's an interesting gameplay loop - though arguably, the game is definitely unbalanced and unfinished.

Upon arriving to an island in the middle of nowhere, you're tasked by a nondescript sea captain to do some heinous crimes against robot-kind.  Screw diplomacy, am I right?  Your first real task is to steal a Drillship, which the entire game will focus around (and actually is the coolest but also most frustrating part of the game).

The Drillship is an upgradeable ship that can burrow into the ground, move around, and resurface at other (specified) locations.  It is your only mode of travel (other than your legs) and you defend it with your life.  Upgrading your Drillship is satisfying, adding new modules and defensive turrets on it to make it look bigger and cooler.  The latest Volcanoids update allows you to decorate it with paints, which, sounds pretty neat but the UI is insanely cumbersome and not for the feint of heart or easily frustrated.  Unfortunately, as cool as the Drillship is (and again, the core focus of the entire game), defending it is super obnoxious.  You can have as many turrets as space, energy, core CPU and ammunition allow - which depending on where you are in the game, can be quite a lot.  But your turrets are always overwhelmed by the robot ARMY, because it really is an army.  On standard difficulty, expect in mid to late game to have cohorts of metallic bastards storm your base as 30+ in number.  Your turrets cannot handle this, and sometimes, neither can you.  An effective strategy is to burrow your Drillship while you run around the overworld, but this causes a limitation: now it can no longer produce resources or equipment.  Modules only function when above ground and powered.  It's risk/reward.

In addition to defending your own Drillship, you obtain new upgrade components by destroying enemy Drillships.  This is another... gripe, for lack of a better word, because again: robot army.  I should mention that I played this game Single Player, and perhaps the added hands could have made the game easier (and potentially more fun), but the game should surely be balanced for Single Player experiences too.  Once you get the attention of a drill ship, prepare to be assaulted by dozens of mean robots vying for your blood.  Oh and their turrets.  Did I mention you, as a lone soldier, have to fight an entire Drillship's staff and their defenses...?  Did I also mention they [i]print new friends[/i]?!  Yea, they do.  Just after you murder a few dozen blocky foes, more and more flood out from their doorways, turning Drillship assaults into a game of attrition: their overwhelming force versus your armour and ammunition (and mental wherewithal).

Admittedly, I think the Drillship is the best part of the game but also the most unbalanced.  The game strongly plays as if it were meant to be multiplayer, because it tends to feel like there is too much for your single person to handle, whether it be offense or defense.

Where the game is lacking is its content.  Partway through the game you come to experience a very obvious path of progression: get zone 1 materials, upgrade Drillship with level 2 parts.  Get zone 2 materials, upgrade Drillship with level 3 parts.  Get zone 3 materials, upgrade Drillship with level 4 parts.  Destroy baddies mixed in there.  The Drillship leads the impression of customization, but in reality its very much a required path with no room for deviation or creativity.  Your ship [i]must[/i] have the next level piece to do X, and another level to do Y, etc.  Volcanoids could benefit from some deviating paths there, which can add longevity to the game.  An example: instead of constantly adding next level tracks to the ship (which increase the speed of the Drillship), maybe a Drillship could have claw legs (which could negatively impact speed, but add the ability to melee robots when they get too close) or rockets for mobility (which could require upgraded hull due to increased heat, also require burning more coal to use, but make you go a hell of a lot faster underground).  This is just a single example I can think of off hand, just to add some variety to the game, instead of forcing the player down an absolute, unchanging and narrow path the game walks you down.  One could argue that there is customization in the modules you build, but let's get real, there isn't.  You need better modules to do better stuff.  Your pistol turrets are going to do nothing against level 3 robot baddies, and you're kissing your ship goodbye if you use that for defense.  You're absolutely forced to build better stuff if you want to actually win the game.

One interesting gameplay mechanic (though might get old depending on your personality) is the volcanic eruption.  Every x number of minutes, based on difficulty or new game customization, the volcano in the middle of the island erupts.  Let's not discuss the fact that all the fauna survive the volcano ash every time, and that it clears up in a few minutes... science doesn't belong in video games, people.  Let's instead focus on the fact that: if you're above ground when the volcano erupts, you simply die.  This means if you're not near your Drillship at the timer countdown, you're screwed.  This can make for some funny or frustrating moments.  I laughed when I trapped myself in an enemy Drillship, because they can open the doors and I cannot, and the timer reached 0.  Oops.  As you progress in the game and need to spend more time assaulting enemy Drillships, this timer becomes more and more annoying than fun.

[b]Gameplay Spoilers Ahead[/b]:
On the topic of unbalance, once you obtain the [spoiler]hand cannon and its explosive ammunition[/spoiler], the rest of the game becomes laughably easy.  As you play, Volcanoids storyline [spoiler]requests you to destroy underground lasers, that are aggravating the magma, causing the volcanic eruptions[/spoiler].  Using the [spoiler]hand cannon[/spoiler], I was able to [spoiler]destroy the last two laser drills with absolute ease, accelerating the end of the game, because the destruction of the final drill is the game win condition[/spoiler].  Knowing how difficult it is to storm high level Drillships, the end game conditions felt... lazy and empty in comparison.  No real challenge, which is unfortunate.  I am also surprised that [spoiler]each drill you destroy doesn't increase the time between the eruption timer, which could help with my criticism above, where higher level Drillships require more time to assault.  I'm surprised it did nothing at all until you blew them all up, really.  Feels weird[/spoiler].

Nevertheless, I provide a positive recommendation.  The game may tout itself as "Open World" when it isn't, and may have a very specific progression path from start to finish, but that doesn't make the game bad; it just makes is... less than it could be.  Volcanoids, with enough love, could turn itself into an amazing game with lots of replayability.  For now, it's a one-trick pony that takes about 15 hours to complete from start to finish.  I reiterate that there is some innovative gameplay here, especially when it revolves around the Drillship and its expansion - though I caution that its defense is annoying, and you may become frustrated with its defense or the assault of enemy drillships, as often times both events feel unfair even on standard difficulty.

Story:

The story is not explained ingame very well, but according to what I pieced together and the info on Steam, there was an island inhabited by humans which was suddenly invaded by killer robots called COGs. They came from underground in drillships and tapped into the power of the island's volcano, making it erupt. The people of the island left, then they sent out an expedition in a submarine with a captain and your player character to drive out the COGs. That's when the game begins.

Gameplay:

The gameplay is very basic, yet conceptually interesting. I started out in the submarine with the captain (who will give you quests to the end of the game). The first task was to mine copper and coal and produce some items using the submarine's modules. My first experience of crafting was pleasantly surprised. While crafting recipes do not seem balanced at all, they are VERY cheap which I liked. I generally only had to go mining once for any given resource until the end of the game. It was very little grind which I really liked, as mining is in my view a tedious and uninteresting task.

There are three map zones and each has one common resource (copper, iron, titanium) and one rare resource spawning close to lava (sulfur, crystal, diamond) and coal. The only resources for which I had to go on more than one mining run were copper, sulfur and coal.

After that, I got sent to claim a damaged COG drillship which was the core of the game. One other important feature of the game was volcanic eruptions. At the top of the screen was a timer and when it ran out the volcano exploded, killing you if you're outside and destroying a drillship if it's not underground, and also respawning resource nodes. This was particularly relevant as I had to fix it and upgrade it a bit. The eruptions were annoying at times, but hardly ever proved a problem.

Here's a quick explanation of how drillships work: they have a number of side wall hull spaces, ceiling hull spaces, core slots and energy. The hull spaces can install various modules and they can get damaged and destroyed, core slots is a cap on how many modules, energy is used to operate most modules. There are also drillship upgrades which come in three categories: core (core, engines), movement (hull, drill, tracks) and tech (research). Core improves stats and allows extra drillship segments, movement allow the ship to go to the other areas on the map, tech unlock new recipes.

EDIT: Drillships move on the map via a network of numbered landing sites. You select a number in the helm and hit the travel lever then wait until you reach the destination. It's somewhat disappointing, as you do not get to actually control the drillship.

The drillship modules are: storage, crafting, refinery, powerplant, turret, research. All provide fairly obvious functionality. Although I will note here that the way storage modules work is pretty nice. Active storage modules provide a ship-wide storage inventory which is compressed in the UI. Rather than having a bajillion item slots, there's only one item per slot with no limit on the number, although stacks are still used in the storage system with each module providing a number of stacks. And it can be accessed from anywhere in the ship. Pretty handy.

The modular drillship basebuilding is actually pretty good. It reminds me of Subnautica somewhat, although it runs from a problem the entire game suffers: a lack of content. More on that later.

My next task after building up the drillship was to attack a lava source and disable it. Lava sources are basically the game's end goal. There's three lava sources in one lava cave in each map zone of 3 and one lava source in the volcano proper. Destroy all of them and the COGs are defeated and you win.

Before I go on, I should go into the combat. The combat in this game is... extremely minimalist. Enemy COGs march at you in a strength line while slowly firing single shots at you. There's different types of COGs but their only difference is in how much HP they have. The player has only two weapons. A double-barrel shotgun with upgradeable ammo and grenades, nothing else. Not even armor. The shotgun is decent, but needs a reload after every 2 shots which can be problematic sometimes. The grenades are effective, but hard to use on COGs. Their real importance is in destroying structures, like enemy drillships and the lava source cranes.

The lava sources each have three cranes holding up some kind of laser beam device which need to be destroyed. Destroying them is the main objective. There is also an enemy drillship in each lava source cave continuously bringing in enemy COGs and there's enemy turrets which require you to take cover and destroy with grenades.

Finishing each lava source was a fairly easy affair. All I needed to do was make sure my drillship's defenses were up to snuff, keep a distance from the enemy COGs, shoot them (or grenade them if they are in mobs), take cover from turrets, grenade them, then grenade the cranes. Done. Attacking the enemy drillship is not necessary and didn't work out when I tried. You have to destroy every bit of hull and I couldn't find a good way to destroy the ceiling hull parts. Grenades hit me as well, shotgun is not good against structures, pickaxe can't reach. So I ignored them.

One issue should be clear though. The combat lacks any kind of depth or tactics. It is very rudimentary, which is a pattern with this game.

After the lava source mission, I was sent to upgrade my tech. The way research works is simple. Marked on the map are spawn locations for tech parts, which you mine with your pickaxe, take back to the ship and research with your research modules. Then add the researched upgrade to the ship core. Very simple, but it takes a lot of time. Research is quite slow.

There's three tech tiers. The first you start with, second is gained in zone 1, third in zone 2. There is also a fourth tier for movement modules which will allow you to enter the volcano.

One major problem I had with tech tiers was that while they unlocked "better" modules, they never felt like a real improvement. Higher tier modules use up more space and they only allow you to utilize the higher tier. Let's take a refinery module for example. A tier 1 uses 1 hull space, 10 core slots, 2 energy and provides 1 refining power. A tier 2 uses 2 hull spaces, 20 core slots, 4 energy and provides 2 refining power. It's basically... the same as 2 tier 1 refineries. It only lets you refine tier 2 materials.

At this point, all game elements have been revealed. There will be nothing new for the rest of the game. I went to area 2, got the new materials there, the new research, upgraded the drillship, destroyed the lava source and proceeded to area 3 where I did the same thing (although there was no research there). Then I went to the volcano, destroyed the lava source there and won the game, getting an ending dialog with some story about how the COGs are defeated and statistics like my playtime and energy produced

PS: I didn't experienced any bugs :)
